entry.title: Latent Consistency Models: How to speedup image generation

link.title: Latent Consistency Models: How to speedup image generation

entry.summary: In a previous post I briefly covered Diffusion Models. And as I pointed out, they have an important drawback that makes them slow at creating new images. We often have to wait minutes for an image to be generated (even with beefy machines!). I’m talking about the “denoising” steps they have to run for generating an image. –Denoising steps of a Diffusion Model to produce an image– Reducing ...

entry.title: Some thoughts on the usage of AI for developing software: Is the end near?

link.title: Some thoughts on the usage of AI for developing software: Is the end near?

entry.summary: – Beware of the following to be quite philosophycal, if you're pragmatic, end the reading here! – In the last post I wrote about how I used AI as an assistant to build a guitar chord website. During that (short) venture I had the opportunity to reflect first hand on the future impact of AI on software development. So that’s what I’m sharing on this post. entry.title: The AI Coder: Building a website using AI

link.title: The AI Coder: Building a website using AI

entry.summary: Last week I decided to tackle a quite silly side-project I left stopped about 2 years ago: building my own (guitar) chord / tab site so I can store all my music sheets. The main motivation for doing this is that I got tired of using UltimateGuitar, from which I’ve been being a user since around 2013. Back then it was vey handy to have a site where I could store all my guitar tabs, search for o...

entry.title: How I generated professional headshots for my LinkedIn profile

link.title: How I generated professional headshots for my LinkedIn profile

entry.summary: The other day I was bored, wandering through LinkedIn and realized that I probably needed some new profile pics. You know, the ones very corporate-guys share on their posts. Something cool with a suit and some office-styled background. So I thought: What if I finetune an image generation model on myself and use it to generate them? How can I generate photos of myself? entry.title: LoRA: How can I tune my model without an expensive GPU?

link.title: LoRA: How can I tune my model without an expensive GPU?

entry.summary: Training neural networks can be really tedious. Both in terms of methodological complexity – tuning hyperparameters, syncing training runs, scheduling learning rates, etc. – and also hardware requirements. That’s why historically large architectures (like ResNet) have been “pretrained”, or trained on broad tasks (image classification, segmentation, object detection, etc) by more-or-less powerf...
